definitions: A negotiable financial instrument issued by a bank to represent a foreign company's publicly traded securities. The depository receipt trades on a local stock exchange, while the underlying shares trade on a foreign exchange.

A certificate issued by a depository bank, representing a specific number of shares of a foreign company's stock. These receipts allow foreign companies to have their shares traded in different markets without having to list on those exchanges directly.
examples: Investors can gain exposure to foreign markets through a depository receipt.
The company issued a depository receipt to attract international capital.
Trading a depository receipt can simplify cross-border investments.
